bboxes.raw_text:
In announcing his candidacy for
Governor of Arizona, Phoenix at
torney. Richard G. Kleindienst,
said that pressing need exists
to continue the kind of progress
sive leadership Arizona has been
given in the past six years.


81 humbly believe" he con-
tinued, "that, because of my
training and background and be-
cause of my knowledge and love
of Arizona, | can provide that
leadership.


GAS a member of a pioneer
Arizona family, it has been my
privilege to have been reared in
our State during a very exciting
period of time. l have had the
opportunity to both observe and
participate in the dynamic growth
of our States wealth, population
and resources. This growth
would not have been possible
without the dedicated efforts of
persons from all walks of life.
The continuation of this growth
requires the constant best eff
forts of us all. We must be able
to meet the new problems which
beset us with sound, positive
programs. We must also main
tain an environment which will
attract jobs and opportunities for
all our citizens.

chapter of the National Associa-
ton for the Advancement Of Col
ored People; attorney Reid Car
lock, and Eugene Marin, teacher
at Lowell School. All are mem
bers Of the Phoenix Human Re-
lations Commission.


The accommodations Commit
tee will investigate charges of
violations of the accommoda-
lions ordinance filed with the
city clerk. 1t is directed to re-
port its findings in writing to
the clerks office within 80 days.

Accomm ODD ton Committee
Chosen BY City Council

Congressman John ]. Rhodes
announced his candidacy for re-
election to the United States
House of Representatives from
District L.


Rhodes, Republican, is seek
ing his seventh straight term in
Congress. The announcement
came at news conference held
this afternoon in the Phoenix
Press Club.


Congressman Rhodes was re-
Gently named spokesman for the
platform committee at the Repub-
lican National Convention next
month. He Is member Of the
powerful House appropriations
Committee, and serves on the
Public Works and the Foreign
Operations subcommittee.


Born in Council Grove, Kansas, .
Rhodes was a 1893 graduate of
Kansas State College, and OBJ
tanned his law degree from Har-
ward Law School in lo4l. He is
a member of the bar in Kansas,
Arizona and the District of Col
umbia.





During World War II. Rhodes
served nearly five years in the
Air Force.


A resident of Mesa, the Con-
gresham is past president of that
Citys Chamber of Commerce,
and the past senior vice COM
mander of the Mesa Post of the
American Legion. Rhodes is a
former vice chairman of the Ari-
iona Board of Public Welfare.

John Rhodes Seeks
His Seventh Term

Benjamin Steele, a resident Of
Phoenix less than two years, an
nounces the opening of Steele's
Tailor Shop. 1854 E. Washington.


He operated tailor and de-
signing shop in Chicago 7 years
before moving west because ofhis
daughters health.


He studied tailoring at Tuske-
gee Institute, Tuskegee, Alabama
and graduated from Masters
College of Fashion Designing in
Chicago.


Mr.. Steele. his wife, Billie,
and four children reside at l402
E. Coronado.


He also opened an import and
export company and janitorial
service.

The Phoenix City Council has
appointed a five-member citizens
committee to administer the pub
lie accommodations ordinance
that becomes law July %.


The public accommodations
committee includes Attorney
Jarril F. Kaplan, chairman. who
played a key role in drafting the
new ordinance: Episcopal Bishop
Joseph M. Harte, the Rev. Luth-
err ]. Harper, Methodist minis
ter and past president Of the state

JACKSON, Miss. - Following
NAACP requests to the US. De-
partment of Justice, James MID
dleton was appointed the first
Negro u. S. Deputy Marshal in
the State of Mississippi this week.
No Negro has ever held this po-
sition here before.


Last June at the time Of Med
ger Evers' funeral, his brother,
Charles Evers. now NAACP Mis-
sissippi field secretary. con-
suited with Attorney General
Robert F. Kennedy concerning the
appointment Of a Negro as US.
Marshal.


Further NAACP correspond
ence with officials in the Depart
ment of Justice resulted in the
appointment Of MIR. Middleton.

lst Negro Marshal
Named In Mississippi

Meeting the Grand Exaer Ruler Hobson Reynolds national
the Improved Benevolent and Protective Order of Eks
of the World, several Elk dignitares.


Greeting him Sky Harbor Airport June % from left
Franklin California: CDD Kermit Cage of Arzona
GELK l. Smith, GER Reynolds of Philadelphia Gr CT Secre-
tary Buen " Kelly Norfolk Va E. E. Bobo PISA convention
chairman l. Smith, PISA president of the womens
division.


The Pacific States Association held in Phoenix
1927. cohosed by the W. H. Patterson Lodge AT
and the Grand Canyon Temple 437.

Delegates National Newspaper Publishers Associa-
the Napa Valley
Winery Saturday. June IT.
tion and luncheon.


panel election of officers also
held publisher Arizona Tribune presided
luncheon meeting Among those who enjoyed the day were
E. Washington Rhodes publisher of the Philadelphia Tribune
retiring Association president; Brother Gregory, winery
ident Louis E. Martini Deputy of the Democratic Ma
pary L. Stanley Sr publisher the Louisville
Defender newly elected president and Joe Make assistant sales
Siche nc distributors The Christian
Brothers products, who arranged the affair.
